result.execSummary:
The defendant Caleb R. Mansfield was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.23(2).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: *Obtain and maintain full-time employment or be enrolled in and attend school full time, or a combination of both resulting in full time.
*Do not have direct/indirect contact with Mr Johnston, J. G., or any of the victims either personally or thru electronic messaging device or telephone, Mr Hutkowski, Mr Bindel and Mark Dexter.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

supervisions.notes:
**Per Court Order /s/ RJS 03/30/21:   incarceration credit due is 421 days in 15CF481
*Eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program
*Eligible for the Substance Abuse Program

Concurrent with: Concurrent with 15CF394 and all other sentences being served

superMiscConds.notes: *Pay restitution, jointly & severally, with co-defendant's in the two cases originally diposed

*Pay costs/surcharges
*Defendant is required to authorize the department to collect funds from the defendant's wages and from other moneys held in the defendant's prisoner's account to be used for payment of obligations in reasonable amounts as determined by DOC. If any fines, costs, surcharges, & restitution remain outstanding at the end of the confinement portion of this sentence, then the remaining balances shall be paid as a condition of extended supervision.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

records.descr: Amended Judgment of Conviction After Revocation

records.addlTxt:
01:35 PM Defendant Caleb R. Mansfield appeared by video with Attorney  John P Runde. Prosecuting Assistant District Attorney (ADA) Robert J Jambois appeared for State of Wisconsin. Attorney  Robert J Jambois appeared by video for Plaintiff State of Wisconsin.  Motion for Sentence Credit is heard today.
ADA Jambois informs the Court the sentence credit history that the state recommend at sentencing.
ADA Jambois believes that the Defendant needs have the prison system calculate and make a calculated determination for credit.
Atty Runde informs the Court that the previous attorney didn't calculate the credit correctly.
ADA Jambois states the Dept of Corrections have people hired to verify the sentence credits especially when there are numerous cases.
  BY THE COURT:  Motion Granted.
JOC 15CF394 amended credit total 296 days 
JOC 15CF481 amended credit total 292 days
Motion hearing on February 11, 2021 at 01:30 pm.

records.descr: Amended Judgment of Conviction After Revocation

records.addlTxt:
Attorney  John P Runde appeared by video for Defendant Caleb R. Mansfield.  Defendant Caleb R. Mansfield appeared by video, in custody. Prosecuting Assistant District Attorney (ADA) Robert J Jambois appeared for State of Wisconsin. 
Cases heard at this time are 19CF-278 for a plea and sentencing hearing and 15CF-481 and 15CF-394 for motion hearings.

11:11 AM Court calls case.
Atty Jambois states appearances.

There is a plea agreement.
Defendant will enter a plea to Count 2.
Count 1 and Count 3 will be dismissed outright.
Prosecutor states plea agreement.
State has complied with victim notification statutes.
Attorney for defendant concurs with agreement stated.

Plea Questionnaire/Agreement filed electronically yesterday.

Defendant enters a plea of: 
19CF-278: Count 2: No Contest.

Parties stipulate to the 102 days credit as stated by Department of Corrections. Parties are requesting the other matters be set over for another date to address days credit.

BY THE COURT:
Court will amend the judgments of convictions in 15CF-394 and 15CF-481 to award 102 days credit and the parties will reserve their rights with respect to arguing additional credit. 

Court questions defendant regarding plea.
Court informs defendant of the constitutional rights. 
Court advises defendant of elements the state must prove for the charge.
Court questions attorney for the defendant.
Court finds defendant's plea is freely, voluntarily, knowingly, and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge.

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge.
Court finds the defendant guilty.  Clerk directed to enter judgment of conviction this date.
19CF-278: Count 1: Dismissed
19CF-278: Count 2: Burglary
19CF-278: Count 3: Dismissed

Court has a number of factors to consider to determine sentencing.

BY THE COURT:
19CF-278:
Count 2:
Jail sentence for 9 months.
Concurrent with other sentences. 
Credit sufficient to satisfied jail sentence.
Time served jail sentence.
State will be permitted 60 days in which to make specific inquiry as to whether or not there is basis for restitution. State to provide that information to Defense and Court.  Assuming there is no objection, the Court will order the restitution and then be convered to civil judgment. If there is a dispute, that will be resolved in a restitution hearing within statutory timelines.
Pay costs and assessments. To be convered to civil judgment. 

Parties to come to joint agreement as to jail credit. 
Atty Runde requests a hearing to be set.
Atty Jambois replies.
Atty Runde explains further. 

BY THE COURT:
Court will not schedule any further proceedings at this time. 
If parties are unable to come to an agreement with remaining credit if any, Court will assume all reasonable efforts have been utilized and expedite a final hearing date.

Letter from the DOC dated 09/23/2020 (previously scanned as document #55 on 09/23/2020) filed by Atty John Runde
   (sent to CM in Br 2 on 12/04/2020 sp)

Exhibit:  Documentation from the DOC dated 10/16/2020 with Supporting Documents filed by Atty John Runde
   (sent to CM in Br 2 on 12/04/2020 sp)
Motion for Sentence Credit
Motion hearing on December 22, 2020 at 11:00 am.
Atty John Runde appointed
from Defendant dated 11-08-2020

REVOKED - SENTENCED TO PRISON

Copy of Court Ordered Financial Obligations
Count 1
**UNSIGNED**  (Attorney to review with client and have signed and returned to Portage County Clerk of Court's Office)

Defendant Caleb R. Mansfield appeared by video. Prosecuting Assistant District Attorney (ADA) Robert J Jambois appeared for State of Wisconsin. Attorney  Jonathan Evans Barnett appeared by phone for Defendant Caleb R. Mansfield.
Cases heard at this time are 15CF-394 (Count 1 and Count 2) and 15CF-481 (Count 1).

11:28 AM Court calls cases.
Atty Jambois states appearances.

Matters are set for sentence after revocation hearings.

Parties have seen the revocation order and warrant, revocation summary.
State is ready to proceed to sentencing.
Atty Barnett states that they are prepared to go forward today.

Atty Jambois addresses the Court regarding sentencing.
Atty Barnett addresses the Court regarding sentencing.
Defendant addresses the Court.

Court has a number of factors to consider to determine sentencing.

BY THE COURT:
15CF-394:
Count 1:
Determinate Prison Sentence for 64 months.
Initial Confinement for 28 months.
Extended Supervision for  36 months.
Eligible for Challenge Incarceration Program.
Eligible for Substance Abuse Program.
Consecutive to 18CF-202.
Court withholds determination of credit for 20 days. Parties may submit filings within the period of time, then the Court will decide if credit is due. If credit is due, it will go to Count 1 in 18CF-202.
Conditions:
No contact with victims Hutkowski, Bindel or Dexter in 481 and 394.
Obtain and maintain full time employment.
Pay restitution, jointly and severally with co defendants in the two cases originally disposed.
Pay costs and surcharges. 

Count 2:
Determinate Prison Sentence for 64 months.
Initial Confinement for 28 months.
Extended Supervision for 36 months..
Eligible for Challenge Incarceration Program.
Eligible for Substance Abuse Program.
Concurrent to Count 1.
Consecutive to 18CF-202.
Conditions:
Comply with conditions in Count 1.
Pay restitution, jointly and severally with co defendants in the two cases originally disposed.
Pay costs and surcharges. 


15CF-481:
Count 1:
Determinate Prison Sentence for 64 months.
Initial Confinement for 28 months.
Extended Supervision for 36 months.
Eligible for Challenge Incarceration Program.
Eligible for Substance Abuse Program.
Concurrent to 15CF-394.
Consecutive to 18CF-202.
Conditions:
Comply with conditions in 15CF-394.
Pay restitution, jointly and severally with co defendants in the two cases originally disposed.
Pay costs and surcharges. 

Court will file determinate sentence and post conviction relief for which the Defense is to get a copy to Defendant. 
Court informs Defendant his right to voting and firearms.
Sentencing hearing on revocation on May 5, 2020 at 11:00 am.
Letter from the Defendant Dated 04/16/2020
Sentencing hearing on revocation on April 28, 2020 at 01:30 pm.

Atty Jonathan Barnett appointed

Defendant Caleb R. Mansfield in court, in custody. Assistant District Attorney (ADA) Robert J Jambois appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Cases heard at this time are 15CF-394, 15CF-481 and 18CF-202. 19CF-278 is pending.

11:21 AM Court calls cases.
Atty Jambois states appearances.

Matter is set for a sentence after revocation hearing.

Defendant appears without an attorney.
Defendant was in Wood County yesterday, was sentenced in front of Judge Potter, did have representation.

Court informs Defendant his right to an attorney/public defender's office.
Defendant replies. 
Defendant has seen the revocation summary.

Court will adjourn this matter.
Defendant may be sent to Dodge Correctional shortly.
State agrees that the matter be set over and requests the public defender's office represent him in the three revocation files and the pending 19CF-278 case.

Defendant addresses the Court as to why Atty Weiland was withdrawn in 19CF-278, was fired.

Defendant does not intend to find his own representation at this time.
Atty Jambois states there may be miscommunication due to the fact that the public defender's office states they had the impression that this Defendant was obtaining his own counsel.

State believes that this Defendant needs an attorney.

Defendant spoke with public defender's office last week about 19CF-278, is waiting for someone to get appointed.

Court will refer the case to public defender's office as to 19CF-278.
Pretrial conference on November 11th will be adjourned to December 30th.

Discussions continue.
Order Permitting Defense Counsel to Withdraw /s/ RJS 10/21/19
Order Permitting Defense Counsel to Withdraw filed by Atty Gregg Waterman
Atty Gregg Waterman appointed
Sentencing hearing on revocation on October 30, 2019 at 11:00 am.
Request for Court Hearing

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: Joshua Hutkowski, Jeffrey Bindel and Mark Dexter
Associated with Charge #1

Defendant Caleb R. Mansfield in court with attorney Jerod Barkley. Defendant Caleb R. Mansfield in custody. Elizabeth R. Constable appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Both files heard: 15CF394 & 15CF481

15CF481 -
Attorney/Defendant received copy of criminal complaint.
Court informs defendant of charges and maximum penalties.
Attorney/Defendant waives reading of complaint.
BY THE COURT: Court finds it is probable that a felony was committed and this defendant committed it and binds the defendant over for trial.

Defendant waives right to preliminary hearing. 
Court questions defendant regarding waiver of preliminary hearing. 
Court questions Attorney.
Court finds the defendant has freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived the preliminary hearing. 
On the defendants waiver of the preliminary hearing, Court determines, based on the facts contained in the complaint, there is sufficient probable cause and binds the defendant over for trial. 
  
State files Information.
Defendant received copy of information.
Defendant waives reading of information. 

15CF394 & 15CF481 -
Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.
State files Statement of Uncharged Read-in.
Prosecutor states plea agreement.
Attorney for Defendant concurs with agreement stated.

Defendant enters a plea of: 
15CF394 all counts - NO CONTEST 
15CF481 - NO CONTEST

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge(s).

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge(s).
Court finds the defendant guilty 15CF394 all counts and 15CF481.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date.

Atty Constable makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 
Atty Barkley makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 

BY THE COURT:
Sentence withheld
Placed on probation for 4 years on each of the counts to which he's plead (except Count 3), concurrent with each other:
Pay costs 
Pay restitution of $4,309.71. Joint and several with his co-defendant, James Johnston. 
Obtain and maintain fulltime employment or enroll in school fulltime or combination of both for fulltime. 
No direct/indirect contact with Mr. Johnston, Jared Gadow, or any of the victims either personally or thru electronic messaging device or telephone, Mr. Hutkowski, Mr. Bindel and Mark Dexter. 
In the event he completes the terms of his probation, expungment is granted in 15CF394 only.

15CF394 Count 3 - 
Serve 102 days jail. 
102 days credit. 
Pay costs. 

State has complied with Victim Notification Statutes.

Court reviews the statement of uncharged read-ins and was relied on during sentencing. 
Atty Barkley makes statements re: expungment.  
BY THE COURT:  Court finds society will not be harmed and the defendant will benefit from expungment.  
Atty Barkley makes additional statements.  Defendant would like to move to MI at some point. 
Atty Constable does not object to the Court permitting the probation to be transferred to MI. 
BY THE COURT:  Court does not object to that either unless some additional requirements for accepting that transfer would impact the elements of the sentence of the Court.  If it does, the court would have to consider those, without know those, it would permit transfer to the state of MI in the event he is accepted for supervision there.
Defendant's Authorization for Attorney to Appear and Act
